column1: Young people not in employment, education or training (NEET)
column5: Part of the UK Government 'Ethnicity Facts and Figures' website. Provides charts and tables on levels of NEET and economic activity amongst young people from minority ethnic groups. Although it uses APS (similar to our analysis), it includes NEET figures which our analysis doesn't.
column7: Includes suitable broad groupings (white, black, mixed, other) with sufficient sample/detail. Does not include Asian, but this is covered by individual groups
column9: Contains suitable groups with sufficient sample/detail for Asian ethnic groups (Bangladeshi, Chinese, Indian, Pakistani, Asian other). However, not included for other broad groups
column15: Gender breakdown included for all ethnic groups (All, Bangaldeshi, Chinese, Indian, Pakistani, Asian other, Black, Mixed, white, other)
column17: Not included
column23: Not included
column29: NEET and economic activity are broken down by ethnic group and sex (sex is the only available demographic variable). These breakdowns are available by all ethnic groups included on the page (All, Bangaldeshi, Chinese, Indian, Pakistani, Asian other, Black, Mixed, white, other)
column33: Main focus is on NEET, and provides data on whether unemployed or inactive
column51: Latest available (correctly weighted) DfE data (2017-2019), but pre-covid. Covers multiple years

column1: Race inequality in the workforce
column2: Operation Black Vote; Centre for Longitudinal Studies; CarnegieUK
column5: Report presenting findings of Next Steps, a longitudinal study of the 'millenial generation' in England. Participants were born in 1989/90, and they have been followed across a number of years since 2004. This report presents findings from a 'sweep' when participants were aged 25. In total, 7,707 participants took part. The report focuses on the relationships between employment, gender, ethnicity and mental health at age 25. In relation to ethnicity, the report considers: the relationship between unemployment, precarious work and ethnicity; and the relationships between ethnicity, work and mental health.
column7: Includes suitable data about 3 broad groupings (white, mixed, other), with sufficient sample size for significance testing. Asian and Black groups are not included, and only partially covered by separate ethnic groups (Indian, Pakistani, Black Caribbean, Black African).
column9: Contains suitable groups with sufficient sample size for significance testing. However, only available for select Asian and black groups (Indian, Pakistani, Bangladeshi, Black Carribean, Black African).
column15: Not included in report, although controlled for in regression analyses (precarious work by ethnicity; predicting mental ill health by ethnicity)
column17: Not included in report, although controlled for in regression analyses (precarious work by ethnicity; predicting mental ill health by ethnicity)
column19: Disability as a whole is not included, but there is a focus on mental illhealth (specifically, predicting mental ill health by ethnicity with income at age 25 as a controlling factor in the regression analysis)
column23: Not included
column27: Cross-sectional analysis of longitudinal study, so focused on young people of the same age (25)
column29: Not available. Although some demographic characteristics controlled for in regression analyses (gender, social class, housing tenure, household income during adolesence, GCSE attainment, mential ill health at a younger age, income at age 25).
column31: Not available. Although some demographic characteristics controlled for in regression analyses (gender, social class, housing tenure, household income during adolesence, GCSE attainment, mential ill health at a younger age, income at age 25).
column33: Detailed employment status provided with breakdowns for all available ethnic groups (white, mixed, Indian, Pakistani, Bangladeshi, black Carribean, black African, other)
column39: Detailed contract type breakdown included (focus on indicators of precarious work). However, scored 2 as only included for white/BAME rather than separate ethnic groups.
column51: Longitudinal dataset (Next Steps) with no new entries, so focussed only on a specific time period (age 25 in 2013).

column1: Facing the facts: ethnicity and disadvantage in Britain
column5: Report with the aims of understanding how socioeconomic outcomes differ between ethnic groups in the UK. Analysis is based on several data sources including ONS Families and Households Survey, ONS Annual Population Survey, and DfE datasets.
column7: Includes suitable data about the broad grouping for the white ethnic group. Some analysis includes broad groupings for black. Analysis that does not include black as a broad grouping is covered by individual groups (Black Carribean and Black African). Asian is not included and is only partially covered by individual groups (Indian, Pakistani, Bangladeshi). Mixed and other groups are not covered.
column9: Contains suitable groups with sufficient sample size for analysis. However, only available for select Asian and black groups (Indian, Pakistani, Bangladeshi, Black Caribbean, Black African).
column15: Some discussion is made on the interaction between gender and ethnicity but this is limited.
column17: Not included
column23: Not included
column29: Some two-way intersectional analysis of proportion of dependent children households decomposed by parental status. Analysis is not focussed on young people and employment outcomes
column33: Unemployment and employment breakdowns by ethnicity groups (White, Indian, Pakistani, Bangladeshi, Black Caribbean, Black African).
column43: Breakdowns of post-graduation earnings by ethnicity are included in the report.
column45: Analysis included on levels of pay 1 year after graduating compared to 10 years after graduation. Proxy for how pay has progressed over the 10 year period for different ethnic groups.
column51: Wide range of data used including ONS Families and Households Survey, ONS Annual Population Survey, and DfE datasets. Data ranges from 2007 up to 2019.

column1: Apprenticeships and diversity in context in Greater Manchester
column5: A GMCA report looking into apprenticeship participation across different ethnicity groups in Greater Manchester. Uses Skills Funding Agency data from the year 2015/16
column7: Includes suitable data and sample size for all the broad census groupings of Asian, Black, Mixed, Other and White (no exclusions). Chinese is sometimes used as an additional group
column9: Contains suitable data for up to 18 ethnic groups however because sample sizes are insufficient analysis is only performed on broader groups  (Asian, Black, Mixed, Other Ethnic Group, White)
column15: Some discussion of gender breakdown for BAME apprentices.
column17: Not included
column23: Analysis of Greater Manchester area only
column25: Some analysis decomposed across Greater Manchester local authorities
column27: Some analysis is decomposed by age band (under 18 and 19-24)
column29: Not available
column33: Data on employment rate, further education rate, and NEET rate of school leavers is included
column35: Includes breakdowns on the subject area/sector that BAME apprentices study
column41: Apprenticeships are the focal point of the analysis
column51: Primary source is from the Skills Funding Agency and only includes analysis for one year (2015/16).

column1: Employment and earning differences in the early career of ethnic minority British graduates
column5: Academic paper analysing the employment outcomes in the early career of ethnic minority university graduates between the years 2004/05 and 2011/12. Uses the Destination of Leavers of Higher Education (DLHE) dataset which includes data on a students' background.
column7: Includes suitable data about the broad grouping for Whites. Asian and Black groups are not included but are covered by individual groups (Bangladeshi, Indian, Pakistani, Chinese, Black African, Black Caribbean). Mixed and Other groups are not included
column9: Contains suitable groups with sufficient sample size for analysis. However, only available for select Asian and black groups (Chinese, Indian, Pakistani, Bangladeshi, Black Caribbean, Black African).
column15: Gender breakdown included for all minority ethnic groups included (White, Chinese, Bangladeshi, Indian, Pakistani, Black Caribbean, African)
column17: All analysis includes proxies for socieconomic status as control variables (Parental social class and type of school attended)
column23: All analysis includes regional characteristics as a control variable
column25: Local authority level included as a control variable in all of the analysis
column27: Model studies only graduates aged 21-24, age kept constant
column29: Economic outcomes are broken down by ethnic group and gender. Gender breakdowns are available for each ethnic group included in the study (White, Indian, Pakistani, Bangladeshi, Chinese, Black Carribean, Black African)

column33: Full breakdowns of employment likelihood relative to white majority (conceputalised as the employment penalty) used as dependent variable in regression analysis
column43: Breakdowns of earnings six months after graduation for all ethnic groups included in the study (White, Black Caribbean, Black African, Indian, Pakistani, Bangladeshi, Chinese)
column45: Labour market trajectories analysed by comparing earnings 6 months after employment to earnings three and a half years after graduation. Breakdowns for some broad groupings (Black African/Caribbean, Indian, Pakistani/Bangladeshi, Chinese)
column49: Includes parent socioeconomic status/background and measurements of local area diversity as control variables
column51: Labour market outcomes are from graduate cohorts between 2004/2005 and 2011/2012 (DLHE).

column1: Labour market disadvantage of ethnic minority British graduates

column9: Contains suitable data and sample size for the major White, Black (Black African, Black Caribbean), and Asian (Bangladeshi, Indian, Pakistani, Chinese) ethnic groups, but excludes others

column19: All analysis includes disability status as a control variable (dummy variable)
column23: All analysis includes regional characteristics as a control variable

column51: Labour market outcomes are from graduate cohorts between 2004/2005 and 2011/2012. (DLHE) labour market trajectories use longitudinal data from cohorts between 2004/2005 and 2008/2010

column1: Moving on Up: Improving employment opportunities for young black men
column5: Evaluation of the Moving on Up initiative. Data collected from 683 individuals who were given employment support, of which 454 have response data. Further analysis performed on smaller subsets of around 454.

column1: London ESF Youth Programme 2014-2020 Phase 1 Evaluation

Data used in this evaluation was collated by the ESFA with additional data coming from a particpant survey and qualitative feedback.

column1: Facing the future: Employment prospects for young people after Coronavirus
column5: L&W report on the focussing on the employment prospects for young people after the Coronavirus pandemic. Uses ONS data combined with online surveys of employers and employees, as well as some focus groups.

column1: Destinations of students after 16 to 18 study
column5: Part of the UK Government 'Ethnicity Facts and Figures' website. Follows ethnic minority students who completed KS4 in the 2016/17 academic year and measures their outcomes in the 2017/18 academic year. Data is taken from the National Pupil Database (NPD) to calculate education destinations. Other data sources from Individualised Learner Record (ILR) and the Higher Education Statistics Agency (HESA) are used to calculate sustained participation in learning.
column7: Includes suitable data and sample size for broad inclusive groupings for Asian, Black, Mixed, Other, and  White. Chinese is also included as a separate broad grouping.
column9: Contains suitable data and sample size for the major White (White British, White Irish, Gypsy/Roma, Irish Traveller, White other), Black (Black African, Black Caribbean), Asian (Bangladeshi, Indian, Pakistani, Asian other), Chinese, Mixed (Mixed White/Asian, Mixed White/Black African, Mixed White/Black Caribbean, Mixed other), and other ethnic groups.
column15: Gender is present in the source data but breakdowns are not available

column1: Social origins and social mobility: the educational and labour market outcomes of the children of immigrants in the UK
column5: Discussion paper that studies the interaction between social origins and the educational and labour market outcomes of second generation immigratns in the UK. Uses ONS Longitudinal Study for England and Wales which spans across five consecutive censuses between 1971 and 2011.
column7: Includes suitable data about the broad grouping for the white ethnic group. Does not include black, but this is only partially covered by individual groups (Carribean). Asian is not included and is only partially covered by individual groups (Indian, Pakistani, Bangladeshi). Mixed and other groups are not covered.
column9: Contains suitable groups with sufficient sample size for significance testing. However, only available for select Asian and black groups (Indian, Pakistani, Bangladeshi, Caribbean).

column1: The returns to undergraduate degrees by socio-economic group and ethnicity
column3: The returns to undergraduate degrees by socio-economic group and ethnicity (ifs.org.uk)
column5: DfE commisioned report that analyses the outcomes of undergraduate education for different socio-economic groups and ethnic minority groupus. Uses the Department for Education’s Longitudinal Education Outcomes (LEO) which links school, university, and tax record for everyone who has taken GCSEs in England since 2002.
column7: Includes suitable data about 2 broad groupings (White and Other). Asian and Black groups are not included but are covered by individual groups (Bangladeshi, Indian, Pakistani, Chinese, other Asian, Black African, Black Caribbean, Black Other). Mixed groups are not included
column9: Contains suitable data and sample size for the major White (White British, White Other), Black (Black Caribbean, Black African, Black Other), Asian ethnic groups (Indian, Pakistani, Bangladeshi, Chinese), and is largely inclusive of others not fitting any of those categories

column17: Significant portion of analysis decomposed by socioeconomic background (SES groups)
column23: Some analysis decomposed by region. Region is also included as a control variable in all of the models.
column29: Labour market outcomes (earnings) are broken down by ethnic group and gender. Gender breakdowns are available for each ethnic group included in the study (White, Indian, Pakistani, Bangladeshi, Carribean)

column49: Some cultural insights such as most common university subject chosen by ethnicity
column51: Uses the Longitudinal Educational Outcomes (LEO) dataset which measures records for everyone who took GCSE's in England since 2002. This report focusses on those who took their GCSE examinations in England between 2002-2007 only

column1: An Unequal Crisis: The impact of the pandemic on the youth labour market
column5: Joint report by IES, YFF, and the Blagrave Trust that anlyses the impact of the pandemic on youth labour markets. Uses data from the Quarterly LFS covering the first lockdown period (April and June 2020) and its easing (July to September 2020)

column1: Apprenticeships and traineeships
column5: Part of the UK Government's explore education statistics website. Presents apprenticeship participation figures from the academic year 2016/17 to quarter 1 of the 2021/22 academic year. Latest data in this release is based on the fourth Individualised Learner Record (ILR) data return from further education and apprentice providers for the 2021/22 academic year. A February 2022 update to this release also includes experimental statistics on course registrations and completions. Does not include regressional models.

column1: When education isn't enough: Labour market outcomes of ethnic minority graduates at elite universities
column5: Report highlighting the labour market outcomes of ethnic minority graduates from Russel Group universities across three academic years (2009/10 - 2011/12) using the DLHE dataset. The sample focusses on graduates who started their degree aged 21 and under, and are not distance learners. The sample size for analysis is 148,220, comprised of approximately 13% ethnic minority respondents

column1: Exploring ethnic differences in the post-university destinations of Russell Group graduates.
column5: Report analysing the differences in the post-university outcomes of ethnic minority Russel Group graduates. Data in this analysis comes throm the Destination of Leavers from Higher Education (DLHE) survey with the sample restricted to those who enrolled at a Russel Group university at the age of 21 and under and who graduated between 2009/2010 and 2012/13. There were a total of 198,430 total valid respondents in the sample. The report also considers the relationships between ethnicity and social backgrounds.

column1: The impact of youth labour market experiences on later employment opportunities: what roles do ethnicity and gender play?
column5: Report examining the relationship between the early labour market experiences of second-generation ethnic minority groups and how they influence later employment outcomes. Data taken from the ONS-longitudinal Study which follows the labour market statuses of young people (aged 16-29 in 2001) over a ten year period (aged 26-39 in 2011). Sample size of 77,180
column7: Includes suitable data about the broad grouping for the white ethnic group. Does not include black, but this is only partially covered by individual groups (Carribean). column13: Analysis focussed on second-generation ethnic minorities
column15: Gender breakdown included for all ethnic groups in the study (White, Bangladeshi, Indian, Pakistani,  Caribbean)

column23: Not included
column29: Economic outcomes are broken down by ethnic group and gender. Gender breakdows are available for each ethnic group included in the study (White, Indian, Pakistani, Bangladeshi, Carribean)

column51: ONS Longitudinal Study dataset covers young people aged 16-29 in 2001 and follows their employment outcomes for 10 years until 2011.

column1: Higher education outcomes: How career satisfaction among graduates varies by ethnicity
column5: Report analysing how ethnicity affects levels of career satisfaction. Data is taken from the final two LDLHE collections (comprising of those who graduated in either 2010/11 or 2012/13) linked with DLHE and the HESA student record.
column7: Includes suitable data about 2 broad groupings (White and Other). Asian and Black groups are not included but are covered by individual groups (Bangladeshi, Indian, Pakistani, Chinese, other Asian, Black African, Black Caribbean). Mixed groups are not included
column9: Contains suitable data and sample size for the major White, Black (Black African and Black Caribbean), and Asian (Bangladeshi, Indian, Pakistani, Chinese, other Asian) ethnic groups, and is mostly inclusive of others not fitting any of those categories
column15: Gender breakdown included for all ethnic groups in the study (White, Bangladeshi, Indian, Pakistani, Black African, Black Caribbean, Chinese, Other, Other Asian)
column17: Includes a proxy for socioeconomic status  (Index of Multiple Deprivation) in the regression model. However, there is limited discussion in the report.
column19: A measure of disability is included as a control in some of the regression models but no discussion is included in the report
column23: A measure of region of domicile and region of employment is included as a control in some of the regression models but no discussion is included in the report. Based on the different regions of UK.
column29: Not available. Although some demographic characteristics controlled for in regression analyses (groupings of variables include: personal characteristics, study characteristics, class of degree, DLHE activity, LDHLE activity/employment, unemployment experience, higher education experience) .
column33: Economic activity is included as a control variable for explaining career satisfaction in some of the regression models. However, limited discussion is made in the report
column35: The sector of employment is included as a control variable for explaining career satisfaction in some of the regression models. However, limited discussion is made in the report
column43: Earnings included as a control variable for explaining career satisfaction in some of the regression models. However, limited discussion is made in the report
column49: Includes a range of relevent variables including family backrground, region, qualification type, and career preparation
column51: The pooled dataset (LDLHE-HESA-DLHE) covers 10 cohorts between the academic year 2002/03 to 2012/13.

column1: Empirical research on Youth Transitions to, and within the labour market
column3: Empirical research on Youth Transitions to, and within the labour market: findings of descriptive and econometric analyses (publishing.service.gov.uk)
column5: Report commisioned by the Department for Business Innovation & Skills with the aim of researching how young people transition into employment. Includes four differnet studies using Labour Force Survey (LFS) data, European Labour Force Survey (EU:LFS) data, various cohort studies (Including National Child Development Study [NCDS], British Cohort Study [BCS], Youth Cohort Study [YCS], Longitudinal Study of Young People in England [LSYPE]), and a merger of National Pupil Data (NPD) of National Client Casework Information System (NCCIS).
column7: Includes suitable data about 3 broad groupings (white, mixed, other), with sufficient sample size for significance testing. Asian and Black groups are not included, and only partially covered by separate ethnic groups (Indian, Pakistani, Bangladeshis, Black Caribbean, Black African).
column9: Contains suitable groups with sufficient sample size for significance testing. However, only available for select Asian and black groups (Indian, Pakistani, Bangladeshi, Black Carribean, Black African).
column15: Gender is included in all models as a control variable but there is no individual breakdown for each ethnicity group
column17: Study uses cohort studies datasets include variables for parental socio-economic background (e.g. number of parents in household and educational attainments of parents. Results are not explained in the report.
column23: Data on different regions in the UK (West Midlands, North East, North West, Yorkshire and the Humber, South West, South East, East of England, East Midlands) are included in the fourth model with discussion on the effects of region on leaving education in the report.  Does not include regional breakdowns for ethnic groups
column29: Breakdowns of likelihoods of different transitions (Education to employment, Education to NEET, Training to NEET, and Training to Employment) by a range of different variables (including ehtnic group and gender)
column33: Employment status breakdowns (whether in education, employment, training, NEET) for labour market transitions.

column51: Includes four different datasets including Labour Force Survey (LFS) data, European Labour Force Survey (EU:LFS) data, various cohort studies (Including National Child Development Study [NCDS], British Cohort Study [BCS], Youth Cohort Study [YCS], Longitudinal Study of Young People in England [LSYPE]), and a merger of National Pupil Data (NPD) of National Client Casework Information System (NCCIS). The NPD/NCCIS merged dataset contained information for the cohort born between 1993/94.
